Imagine you were around just after the big bang. You would be inside a slowly cooling and expanding plasma of Hydrogen and Helium ions at a temperature of trillions of degrees Kelvin. All you would 'see' is a white hot fireball, like being inside the Sun.


 After 380,000 years the temperature would have dropped to an orange hot 3,000 degrees (at a density a million times less than that found in a laboratory vacuum) and the plasma will start to turn to a neutral gas as the electrons and ions combine to form atoms for the first time.


 The gas will no longer interact with light and the entire universe will look dark. As the speed of light is finite, you will still receive radiation from the space around an intensely hot glow of invisible infra-red radiation. If you had an infrared camera you would still see the glow of the fireball which is still coming towards you from every direction.


The heat from this radiation will gradually decrease until becoming room temperature after about 15 million years, which is when gravity started to form the seeds of galactic structures.


Now the temperature of the radiation that is still traveling towards us from the past (from the edge of the observable universe) is 2.73 Kelvin.

You agree, at least, that things can change.  Organisms can become better suited to their environment as we go forward in time.  If the environment changes, the organism can change with it. Change can be a good thing.  For example, when all humans lived in Africa, we all had large amounts of melanin in our skin to protect us from harmful radiation.  As parts of our species migrated away from the equator, protection from the sun was less important.  Additionally, it became more difficult to get vitamin D from the sun.  Humans with lower concentrations of the pigment could more easily produce vitamin D, so over time Northerners' genes coded for a different kind of skin.

That's why sibling inbreeding tends to have such high rates of birth defects over successive generations. Any mutations already carried (whether visibly or not) by the siblings from their parents become stable very quickly because two identical sets of genetic instructions for that mutation get passed on instead of just one. Not all mutations are as extreme as lobster hands and harlequin ichthyosis, but they work the same in how they're carried on.

DNA is very complex, and evolution is even moreso in its machinations, and takes many, many years to occur even in small amounts. A "genetic lottery" is actually a very good analogy for it. The chances of an initial mutation happening are very slim, but over time, if the genetic instructions left behind by the mutation are passed along, and become more stable through successive breeding, and it's easier for that mutation to manifest in the descendants of that first individual.

The CMB will eventually disappear, but not for the reason you're thinking.  Space is huge and the chances of any given photon impacting a solid is staggeringly low.  And space is expanding all the time, so that chance is getting lower.

I think that you are confusing the terms "theory" and "hypothesis."  A hypothesis is an unproven testable statement, like how you (if I am understanding you correctly) are referring to the Big Bang theory.  A theory, however, is a hypothesis that has substantial experimental evidence in its favor and that is accepted by a majority of experts.  Because it is called the Big Bang *theory* and not the Big Bang *hypotheses*, it can be inferred that it is not bs, but an experimentally validated idea.
